Meet the Experts

What's the difference between tanning and bronzing?

In the early aughts, tanning beds were commonly used to accelerate a sun-kissed glow in addition to lying out in the sun. “Tanning involves exposing your face and body to UV rays, either naturally from the sun or using tanning beds. While tanning can make skin appear darker, it's a sign of skin damage and carries risks like premature aging and an increased risk of skin cancer.,” Briceno explains. To avoid harming your skin, Briceno says to look into self-tanning formulas, “which darken the skin over time and often last for days without damaging your skin.” On the other hand, “bronzing is more of a cosmetic and temporary option. It uses tinted products to instantly add warmth and radiance to the skin without significant health risks.” Looking closely, many bronzing formulas boost radiance through tiny gold particles. “When selecting the right shade of bronzer, consider your skin type, complexion, skin undertones, and how you naturally tan in the sun,” Briceno advises.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

What are the best practices when bronzing the body?

Similar to makeup, skin prep is paramount when dealing with body bronzers. “Exfoliate your face and body for a smoother skin texture. I like Andalou Clarifying Yuzu Grapefruit Body Wash, which gently exfoliates with salicylic acid and evens out skin tone for a smooth canvas to start with,” he says. From there, you want to skip any oil-based lotions or creams to ensure the bronzing formula can apply evenly.

“When applying the bronzer, build the intensity gradually, starting with a light layer to avoid streaking and over-darkening. I like blending the bronzer on the body downward, following how the sun hits your body naturally. Don't forget the ears, neck, and hands to create a natural bronze illusion,” he explains. Most bronzing formulas can be applied using your hands; however, using a brush or a mitt can make application easier and less messy.
